title: 110_s3642
content: The Act is titled the "Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Enhancement Act of 2008" and includes findings. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 aims to improve access to safe water and sanitation in developing countries through specific policy objectives and strategies outlined by the Secretary of State. It also aligns with Target 10 of the United Nations Millennium Development Goals to reduce the proportion of people without access to safe drinking water. The United Nations General Assembly declared 2008 as the International Year of Sanitation to recognize the impact of sanitation on public health, poverty reduction, and social development. Congress passed H. Con. Res. 318 in support of the goals and ideals of the International Year of Sanitation, emphasizing the importance of sanitation on public health and the environment. Progress is being made on safe water and sanitation efforts. More than 884 million people lack access to safe drinking water, and 2 out of every 5 people lack basic sanitation services. The health consequences include nearly 10% of the global burden of disease and over 2 million deaths annually. Climate change will worsen water availability, with 2.8 billion people in 48 countries facing severe water shortages by 2025. The impact of water scarcity on conflict and instability is evident in many parts of the world, including the Darfur region of Sudan. To further the United States contribution to safe water and sanitation efforts, it is necessary to expand foreign assistance capacity and represent water-related issues at the highest levels of foreign assistance deliberations. The Act aims to enhance the US Government's ability to implement the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005. It focuses on developing the government's capacity in this area. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to establish the Office of Water within the United States Agency for International Development. The Office will be led by an Assistant Administrator for Safe Water and Sanitation, focusing on providing safe, affordable, and sustainable drinking water, sanitation, and hygiene. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to establish the Bureau for International Water within the Department of State to address global freshwater issues, including safe drinking water, sanitation, and river basin management. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to establish the Bureau for International Water within the Department of State to address global freshwater issues, including river basin and watershed management, transboundary conflicts, agricultural and urban productivity of water resources, pollution mitigation, and adaptation to hydrologic change due to climate variability. International freshwater issues are to be represented within the United States Government and in key diplomatic, development, and scientific efforts with other nations and multilateral organizations. SEC. 5 of the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 is amended to include an assessment of the US Government's efforts in reaching the goal of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. Recommendations are also provided on how the US Government can help achieve this goal if its efforts were proportional to its share of the world's economy. SEC. 6 of the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 focuses on developing local capacity by amending sections and introducing a Water and Sanitation Managers Training Program. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 aims to establish a program to train local water and sanitation managers in priority countries to improve access to safe drinking water and sanitation. The program will be coordinated by designated country water managers and may expand to additional countries as needed. The Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 aims to establish a program in priority countries to train local water and sanitation managers, designate safe drinking water and sanitation as a strategic objective, appoint in-country managers, and coordinate with relevant agencies to further the Act's purposes. SEC. 7. GRANTS FOR LOW COST CLEAN WATER AND SANITATION TECHNOLOGIES. Amends the Foreign Assistance Act to provide grants through the United States Agency for International Development for developing low-cost and sustainable technologies for clean water and sanitation in high priority countries with limited resources. SEC. 8. UPDATED REPORT REGARDING WATER FOR PEACE AND SECURITY. SEC. 8. UPDATED REPORT REGARDING WATER FOR PEACE AND SECURITY. The report must assess political tensions over water sources and the impact of climate change on water supplies in the next 10, 25, and 50 years. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorizes appropriations for fiscal year 2009 and beyond to implement this Act. SEC. 10. CONSTRUCTION. This Act must align with the Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005 and not override its implementation.
